g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Singleton Ensure a class only has one instance, and provide a...
g.text: SingletonEnsure a class only has one instance, and provide a global point of access to it.

g.title: Rectangle.47
g.desc: Clients require global accessibility to the same instance
g.text: Clients require global accessibility to the same instance

g.title: Folded Corner.41
g.desc: The Singleton design pattern allows global access to a partic...

g.text: The Singleton design pattern allows global access to a particular instance. A common Use Case is that a particular instance is required in most parts of our system. Passing around this object, via dependency injection, to each instance of our system becomes cumbersome. A logging instance might be an example of such an object. A logging instance is often used in a software system. The Singleton design pattern proposes to centralize the accessibility of such an object to overcome an extensive Dependency Injection model. Global accessibility should however be approached with care. A logging instance is a ‘good’ example, because it does not control the execution of business logic. Communication is unidirectional, from client to logging instance. I.e. removal of the logging instance, means nothing changes in test nor product execution flow. Software systems that do have global instances, whom influence the execution flow, can be hard to test and understand. This is because the relation is embedded and the Singleton instance can be modified from ‘everywhere’.

g.title: Folded Corner.20
g.desc: The Singleton design pattern compliments the Open Closed prin...

g.text: The Singleton design pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by allowing change of global, accessible logic with minimal modification. This enhances the stability of the code base. All aspects are compared against an implementation where global, accessible logic is concrete, static or within a namespace. Stability, because the Singleton design pattern allows ‘swapping’ of the implementation without modification of the clients. The Singleton design pattern is an Object Oriented (OO) approach of global accessible logic. This allows use of an interface between client and Singleton. In case the Singleton implementation needs to change, only the static ‘Instance’ function requires adaptation. The rest of the Singleton logic can be overridden and redefined. This way, the clients remain ‘untouched’, which ensures product and test code stability. In contrast, using namespaces, static or concrete classes do not provide this flexibility. Client modification would be required in this case, risking the chance of breaking stable code.

g.title: Rectangle.57
g.desc: Global accessible logic must be (dynamically) changeable
g.text: Global accessible logic must be (dynamically) changeable

g.title: Folded Corner.59
g.desc: The Singleton design pattern is an Object Oriented approach o...

g.text: The Singleton design pattern is an Object Oriented approach of enabling global accessible logic. A common Use Case is that global accessible logic must be flexible to change. The flexibility property can not be achieved when the logic is defined within a namespace or static class. In this case, all clients would have to be modified when the global logic changes. The Singleton design pattern proposes to encapsulate this logic within an object and allow global accessibility to that object. This Object Oriented approach allows the functionality with the Singleton to be Virtual (except for the static ‘Instance’ function, responsible for singleton instantiation and accessibility). The Singleton class can be sub-classed and re-defined. As a result, clients do not require modification when the Singleton instance must be changed. The only place that requires modification, is the ‘Instance’ function of the Singleton. There the instance must be substituted. For example, a logging instance might need the flexibility to change during runtime. I.e. based on runtime conditions a different logging instances must created. The Singleton design pattern can realize this flexibility while being global accessible to all clients.

g.title: Folded Corner.62
g.desc: The Singleton design pattern violates the Single Responsibili...

g.text: The Singleton design pattern violates the Single Responsibility on client side by embedding the Singleton dependency within the client. This results in an ‘implicit’ class /object relation. This implicit relation has negative impact on the readability, testability and reusability. All aspects are compared against an implementation where the client’s dependency is injected and not globally accessible. Readability, because the dependency is embedded within the client(s), so it will be harder to understand the dependency model and flow of a system. The more clients modify the global instance (= Singleton), and that modification has impact on other business rules, the harder it will be to understand the source and execution sequence of a program. This negatively influences the understandability of the code. Testability, because mocking a Singleton can be difficult due to the use of static and lack of Dependency injection. The Singleton functionality can however be made virtual (as discussed in the ‘When?’ section). This allows sub-classing, but not all the assets to enable mocking. The problem is that the Singleton ‘Instance’ function is static and to make it use the mock, change would be required. As a result, testability of client code will be less isolated and more complicated. Less isolated testing means an increased problem window, making it harder to find issues. More complicated, because the Singleton instance (if possible) has to be set in a ‘correct’ state. As an addition to the testability aspect, in case the Singleton instance influences the control flow of the business rules, then a dependency might arise between test suites. E.g. class X under test manipulates the Singleton, this influence class Y under test. In case the Singleton cannot be manipulated ‘appropriately’ during the set-up of test suite Y, there is a need to change the order of test execution. This is can lead to fragile tests that are hard to implement. Reusability, because the dependency is embedded within the client, which complicates client re-use. The Singleton dependency is queried directly from a static function. This disallows client re-use without having the static Singleton function in place. The problem can be mitigated by ensuring that clients are dependent on a partial, virtual Singleton. This means the Singleton can be sub-classed and redefined. This however still means that the static Singleton function must be re-defined, but this approach might simplify re-use.

g.title: Rectangle.67
g.desc: The number of objects that are created from a class should be...
g.text: The number of objects that are created from a class should be restricted

g.title: Folded Corner.69
g.desc: The Singleton design pattern enables restriction of object in...

g.text: The Singleton design pattern enables restriction of object instantiation of a class. A common use case is that only a single instance of a specific class should be created. This constrain could be important to guarantee safety and to overcome malfunctions (=bugs) in a software system. For example, the control of a robotic arm in a medical system. The arm control logic might cause human/system danger when instantiated twice (or more). The danger arises from (accidental) multiple points of control. Another example, a logging instance, that is used throughout the entire software system. Each sub-system should interact with the same logging instance to overcome scattered log files or conflicting situations. The Singleton design pattern constraints class instantiation, while providing OO advantages.

g.title: Folded Corner.102
g.desc: The Singleton design pattern compliments and violates the Ope...

g.text: The Singleton design pattern compliments and violates the Open Closed principle. The Singleton design pattern is used to restrict instantiation of an object to a single instance and provide global access to it. This might be an initial requirement of a software system. However, when later this requirement changes and there is a need to allow more objects of a particular class, then the system might need to change drastically. E.g. a class Person uses Singleton instance Phone. The system requirements change and class Person must be instantiated twice, both with different Phone objects. The Singleton constraints this requirement. To comply to this requirement, we might modify the Singleton to retrieve a different Phone object every time it is called. This however might not be a suitable solution, because sometimes shared ownership of the Phone object is required and sometimes not. To realize the flexibility, a redesign of class Person must be done. The class Person must have the capability of injection of an Phone object. On top of that, the Phone class must change to enable multiple instantiates. These changes, on a large scale, might be catastrophic, because it not only impacts product code, but also the test code. This greatly impacts the stability of the system.
